speaker: Mr Cox (Kingston) (12.09 P.m.)
theText: The Treasury Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1)7298 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 25 September 2002 stration) (12.11 p.m.)-I thank the honourable member for Kingston for his support of this particular legislation. The purpose of this bill, the Treasury Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002, is to clarify the operation of two acts-and the member for Kingston referred to that in his speech-the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act 2001 and the General Insurance Reform Act 2001. The bill is of a minor and technical nature and is designed to ensure that these two acts have their intended effects. The Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act and the General Insurance Reform Act both amended the Insurance Act 1973 for different purposes. The Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act, among other things, amended the Insurance Act to enable modernisation of APRA’s data collections from general insurance companies. The General Insurance Reform Act amended the Insurance Act to substantially strengthen the prudential supervisory requirements for general insurers operating in Australia. The provisions of the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act which amended the Insurance Act and the General Insurance Reform Act both commenced on 1 July this year. It had originally been intended that the provisions of the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act amending the Insurance Act would commence on 1 October last year, in advance of the commencement of the General Insurance Reform Act. A proclamation was made to the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act with this intent. On this basis, the General Insurance Reform Act was drafted as though the provisions of the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act which amended the Insurance Act had already commenced. However, it was subsequently determined that, due to a technical difficulty, the proclamation of the provisions of the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act which purported to amend the Insurance Act was ineffective. As a result, another effective proclamation was made. The effect of this was that the two acts, both amending the Insurance Act, and in some cases the same provisions of the Insurance Act, commenced on the same day. tary to the Minister for Finance and Administration. question? the government not only did not get it right the first time but did not get it right at its second go-and that we are now back fixing the problem? matter of finetuning. This has introduced some uncertainty as to which amendments to the Insurance Act were designed to commence first. This bill makes it clear that the amendments to the Insurance Act contained in the Financial Sector (Collection of Data-Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Act commenced before the amendments contained in the General Insurance Reform Act. I commend this particular bill also to the chamber. Question agreed to.

speaker: Mr Slipper
theText: I think that my friend opposite is being a little harsh. Really, this is more aWednesday, 25 September 2002 MAIN COMMITTEE 7299 Bill read a second time. Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment. Main Committee adjourned at 12.16 p.m. The following answers to questions were circulated: Immigration: Visa Overstayers (Question No. 550) Ms Vamvakinou asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 18 June 2002: (1) What is his Department’s estimate of foreigners working illegally in Australia each year from 1996 to 2001. (2) How many illegal visa overstaying foreigners were removed each year from 1996 to 2001. (3) What was the cost of locating and removing over stayers each year from 1996 to 2001. (4) What departmental measures have been taken to reduce the number of over stayers. (5) Does this Department plan a crackdown on the location and removal of overstayers; if so, what is the extent of the proposed measures. (1) It is not possible to provide a meaningful estimate of the number of non-citizens working illegally in Australia at any given point in time. This is because some non-citizens will have valid visas but be breaching conditions attached to those visas, whilst others will be working while they have overstayed their visa or are otherwise illegally in Australia. However in March 1999 the Government appointed an external Reference Group to guide a review of the issue of illegal workers in Australia. The Reference Group’s report, entitled ‘Review of Illegal Workers in Australia’ was released in November 1999. In the report the Reference Group estimated that 50 per cent of unlawful non-citizens are working illegally. The Reference Group also noted that the number of lawful visitors working in breach of their visa conditions was unknown. Based on the estimate of the Reference GroupI provide the following table. The table covers estimates of overstayers and the consequent number of Illegal Workers going back to the year 2000. Overstayer figures prior to 2000 were derived using a different, less accurate methodology than that currently being used and are not statistically comparable to the current estimates. Period Ending Estimated Number Estimated Number of 30 June of Overstayers* Illegal Workers 2001 60,000 30,000 2000 59,000 29,500 (2) The table below provides the number of unlawful non-citizens and people breaching their visa conditions who have left Australia as a result of Departmental compliance action in the years 1995/1996 to 2001/2002. These figures exclude fishermen, stowaways, smugglers, deserters and unauthorised boat arrivals. Financial Year Total Removals 2001/2002 9,504 2000/2001 9,054 1999/2000 8,996 1998/1999 8,054 1997/1998 7,474 1996/1997 5,654 1995/1996 5,381 (3) Because of the wide range of other activities done in the compliance program (for example employer information, program integrity checking, visa cancellation and the removal of unauthorised boat arrivals) it is not possible to derive actual costs associated solely with the location and removal of overstayers. However to give some indication of the costs involved in the first eleven months of 2001/2002 it is estimated that my Department spent just under $30m in locating a total of 15,892 persons. For the same period it is estimated that approximately $14m was spent on removing 9,852 persons (this in-
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:cludes unlawful non-citizens, people breaching their visa conditions, fishermen, stowaways, smugglers, deserters and unauthorised boat arrivals). (4) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) is actively working on a number of onshore and offshore measures to reduce the number of overstayers in Australia. These measures include: A network of specialist compliance officers located overseas to liaise with authorities such as local police and immigration officers to combat the number of people arriving in Australia illegally. In association with other Government agencies, measures to enhance border surveillance systems and deter illegal migration. The whole-of-government approach to preventing people smuggling and illegal migration has ensured that attempted breaches of Australian borders are detected and intercepted. Onshore compliance officers undertake regular field operations in both metropolitan areas and rural areas of Australia. Some of the field operations are organised in conjunction with other agencies such as Federal/State police, Centrelink and ATO officers. The development of successful relationships with employers, educational institutions, and other Government agencies to gain the cooperation of the Australian community in assisting the Department locate overstayers. Compliance teams are set up which target certain risk areas identified for the program. As examples such teams may focus on illegal worker and employer awareness campaigns, failed ministerial intervention applications, failed appeals to merits review tribunals and student compliance. Implementation of a number of the recommendations of the Review of Illegal Workers in Australia. These include measures to discourage employers from employing illegal workers, including overstayers, as well as information to assist employers to identify illegal workers. (5) DIMIA plans to maintain its active and ongoing program of detection and removal of overstayers and persons breaching their visa conditions. These people are located through our regular field operations and through the action of Federal, State and Territory police forces and other agencies. Newcastle Electorate: Employment of Disabled (Question No. 587) Ms Grierson asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 June 2002: How many people with a disability are employed by the Minister’s Department or agencies under the Minister’s administration in the electoral division of Newcastle. The two agencies within my portfolio that have staff in the Newcastle electorate are the Australian Customs Service (ACS) and the Family Court of Australia. It should be noted that individual employees are not required to provide information about a disability they may have. Employees may choose voluntarily to identify themselves as having a disability, either prior to commencement or during the course of their employment. I am advised that no employees in the ACS or the Family Court in Newcastle have identified themselves as persons with a disability. Foreign Affairs: Western Sahara (Question No. 625) Ms Plibersek asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 June 2002: What is the Australian Government doing to assist the resolution of conflict over self-determination for Western Sahara, particularly in relation to his representations to the Moroccan Government on this issue. lows: The Government supports the early holding of a referendum to determine the wishes of the population of Western Sahara on the question of independence or incorporation into the Kingdom of Morocco, so long as that remains the only process endorsed by the UN for resolving the dispute. On 30 July 2002, the UN Security Council adopted Resolution 1429, extending the mandate of the United Nations Mis-

Novartis Animal Health (Question No. 659) Ms Gillard asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: Has his Department issued a purchase order in the last 12 months to Novartis Animal Health of Pendle Hill, NSW. My Department has advised that it has no record of a purchase order being issued to Novartis Animal Health of Pendle Hill, NSW, in the last 12 months. Australian Defence Industries: Sale (Question No. 672) Mr Murphy asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Further to the answers to parts (2), (6) and (7) to question No. 394 provided by the Minister for Finance and Administration, will he answer those parts to question 394 left unanswered by that Minister. (2) Will he provide details of the advice, if any, he gave to the Minister for Finance and Administration prior to the sale of the assets. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (Part 2) The security of contractual and other relevant information held by ADI is monitored through the Department of Defence contract management processes and the Defence Industrial Security Program, which is managed by the Defence Security Authority. (Parts6 and 7) There are no strategic military assets in private (ADI Group) hands. However, ADI operates facilities at Benalla, Mulwala and Garden Island (Sydney) that have industry capabilities regarded by Defence as important for the support of Australian Defence Force capability. The Benalla facility is owned by the ADI Group and the facilities at Mulwala and Garden Island remain Commonwealth-owned and are leased to ADI. The Commonwealth’s interests in respect of all of these capabilities are adequately protected through appropriate contractual arrangements, including the industrial security requirements discussed in part (2) above. (2) No. However, there was full consultation between the former Ministers for Defence and Finance when they jointly developed options for the Government’s consideration on how best to proceed with ADI’s sale. Health: Fertility Rates (Question No. 681) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Further to paragraph 1 of the answer to part (3) of question No. 495, when will the Government’s review be concluded. (2) Will a report of the review be made available to the public; if not, why not. (3) Further to paragraph 2 of the answer to part (3) of question 495, how does the Government propose to promote public debate and discussions to inform future policy, particularly as they relate to Australia’s falling fertility rates.
title: Representatives Main Committee Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:the honourable member’s question: (1) & (2) There is no formal review. There is no plan for a written report on fertility rates as a policy issue. (3) Public debate and policy consideration of this issue is ongoing and occurs in the context of family policy and a broad range of social and economic issues. Aviation: Point Cook Airfield (Question No. 701) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Further to the Government’s announced sale of Point Cook Airfield, (a) is the Government intending to offer the property for sale as freehold or leasehold and (b) what have been the considerations given to the alternative forms of sale. (2) What is the anticipated sale price. (3) When does the Government anticipate the property will formally be offered for sale. (4) What national or international environmental classifications are associated directly or indirectly with the Point Cook site. (5) What specific environmental audit or audits of the site have been commissioned by or on behalf of the Defence Estates Organisation. (6) Has the Government discussed the environmental condition of the site with the Victorian Environment Protection Authority. (7) How does the Government intend to deal with any potential findings of environmental contamination of the site ahead of the sale being finalised. (8) What is the current value of the RAAF Museum collection at Point Cook. (9) What annual funding has been allocated by the Government or the RAAF to the RAAF Point Cook Museum in each year between 1990 and 2001. (10) How does the Government intend for the RAAF Museum to continue operations within a privately owned site, and what funding will the Government, either through the RAAF or other sources, deliver recurrently to the RAAF Museum. (11) Has the Government had any discussions with Victorian Government museum representatives about the relationship that might be developed between the RAAF Point Cook Museum and other museums in Victoria. (12) What provision is being made for the upgrading of electricity, sewerage and road services to the Point Cook site ahead of its sale. (13) How many RAAF personnel were housed on the Point Cook site at 1 August 2002, and how many of the children of the RAAF personnel attend the Point Cook Primary School. (14) When does the Government envisage RAAF personnel will depart the Point Cook site. (15) What are the current air traffic control arrangements at Point Cook. (16) What are the minimum air traffic control arrangements that the Government will require for any private owner to maintain. (17) What provision will be made for changes in minimum air traffic control arrangements at Point Cook if, after the date of sale, recommendations are made for increased control services out of the late-July 2002 collision and fatality at Moorabbin airport. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) and (b) Initial planning anticipated the disposal of the site was as a freehold sale. Defence is currently considering a proposal for a leasehold sale and a recommendation will be provided to the Government once that consideration has been finalised. (2) Defence has not yet sought a market valuation for the property from an independent authority such as the Australian Valuation Office. A market valuation will be sought once the property is ready
title: Representatives Main Committee Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer tofor marketing. The valuation will be commercial-in-confidence as its release may prejudice the sale price. (3) It is anticipated the property will be offered for sale in the 2002/03 financial year, although revenue is not anticipated until the 2003/04 financial year. (4) It is understood that the environmental classifications associated with the Point Cook site are covered by the Register of the National Estate, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act and the Victoria Planning and Environment Act. (5) In January 1996, a Victorian EPA Accredited Environmental Auditor– Contaminated Land, undertook a Statutory Environmental Audit of a 6.159 ha portion of the site as part of a proposal to establish the National Air& Space Museum of Australia. Additionally, there have been a number of other environmental and related assessments conducted on the site, which are currently being reviewed. (6) Yes. (7) Defence is undertaking further investigation to complement the existing environmental information and gain a comprehensive understanding of issues on the property. Where appropriate, Defence will undertake remediation consistent with future land use; however, all information on the site condition will be made available to potential purchasers. (8) A major stocktake program is currently underway to catalogue and value the RAAF heritage collection. It is currently conservatively valued at $40million. (9) Annual operating allocations for RAAF Museum, excluding salaries, have been: Year $million 1990/91 0.250 1991/92 0.250 1992/93 0.250 1993/94 0.500 1994/95 0.506 1995/96 0.467 1996/97 0.345 1997/98 0.500 1998/99 0.486 1999/2000 0.500 2000/01 0.619 2001/02 0.611 (10) It is intended that the precinct occupied by RAAF Museum will remain under a form of Commonwealth control after the sale of Point Cook. It is anticipated that recurrent Museum funding will remain consistent with current funding levels. (11) RAAF Museum works closely with the Australian War Memorial in regard to advice and expertise on aircraft and technical equipment. RAAF Museum has a working relationship with other institutions, such as the Museum of Victoria, in providing advice on technical equipment that may be acquired by those institutions. (12) No consideration has been afforded to the upgrade of these services. Defence is disposing of the site on an “as is” basis. (13) As at 15 August 2002 (figures as at 1 August 2002 not readily available) there were 19 Defence families occupying married quarters on Point Cook base, not all of whom are posted to RAAF Williams, and 126 single or unaccompanied members, predominantly students, occupying single living-in accommodation. Defence does not maintain data on the schools attended by Defence personnel. However, I understand that there are approximately 10-12 Defence children at Point Cook Primary School. (14) The majority of RAAF personnel will depart the site when the RAAF College is relocated by approximately 2005. A small cadre of RAAF personnel will remain within RAAF Museum and Australian Airforce Cadet billets on the site indefinitely. (15) The Point Cook airfield is an unlicensed airfield. Aircraft using the airfield are required to have signed an Airfield Use Agreement and have it lodged with KFPW, Defence’s property manager for leases and licences at the site. An Airfield Manager contracted by Defence monitors air movements. The air traffic control tower is not in operation. The current air traffic control arrangements are for Mandatory Broadcast Zone operations. (16) The Commonwealth will not have any minimum air traffic control arrangements. Air movements after the sale of the property will be the responsibility of the new owner. The Wyndham City Council has advised that it has adopted a figure of 100,000 movements per year for planning purposes in the area. Defence has incorporated this figure into one of the scenarios developed in considering the possible future strategic land use. Any formal air traffic arrangement will be the responsibility of the State and/or local government. (17) This will be an issue for the new owner and the State authorities to determine. Telstra: Services (Question No. 702) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) What specific improvements in Telstra services have been achieved in the Albury Wodonga region since April 2002, and what is the specific methodology used to demonstrate any improvement. (2) What specific improvements in Telstra services have been achieved in the Gippsland South region over the past 12 months, and what is the methodology for demonstrating any improvement. (3) What specific improvements in Telstra services have been achieved in the (a) eastern and (b) northern suburbs of Melbourne since 1 January 2002, and what is the methodology for demonstrating any improvement. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question based on information provided by Telstra: The Customer Service Guarantee (CSG) is part of the Government’s comprehensive regulatory safety-net. The CSG requires telephone companies to meet specified timeframes for the connection and repair of telephone services for residential and small business customers, or pay compensation. Timeframes under the CSG for service connection have been progressively tightened since its introduction. Compliance with the CSG has been used as an indicator of service performance in relation to new connections (Service Activations) and fault repairs (Service Assurance) in the following answer. It should be noted that CSG performance can be adversely affected by factors outside Telstra’s control such as extreme weather and other seasonal factors, especially when looking at defined geographical areas. The following figures provided by Telstra are based on Telstra’s Service Regions. (1) Telstra has advised that CSG compliance figures for Service Assurance in the Albury/Wodonga Region improved from 85.5% in April 2002 to 92.5% as at June 2002. Over the same period CSG figures for Service Activation moved from 92% to 94.8%. (2) CSG performance for Service Assurance in the Gippsland Region averaged 93.1% for the period July to November 2001. In December 2001, the Gippsland Service Area was expanded to include the Seymour area and is now known at the South Eastern Service Delivery Area. From December 2001 to June 2002, CSG Assurance performance for the South Eastern Service Delivery area averaged 93.3%. CSG performance for Service Activation in the Gippsland Region averaged 95.8% for the period July to November 2001. In December 2001, the Gippsland Service Area was expanded to include the Seymour area and is now known as the South Eastern Service Delivery area. From December 2001 to June 2002, CSG Activation performance for the South Eastern Service Delivery area averaged 95.3%. (3) The eastern and northern suburbs of Melbourne are serviced by one Telstra service region. This area is bounded by Ferntree Gully and Kinglake in the east and Coburg and Sunbury in the west. Telstra has advised that CSG performance for Service Assurance in this area has improved from 91% in January 2002 to 97% at June 2002. CSG figures for Service Activation rose from 94% in January 2002 to 95% as at June 2002.
title: Representatives Main Committee Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the ArtsDepartment of the Prime Minister and Cabinet: Drug Programs (Question No. 724) Ms Burke asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any programs relating to illicit drug use. (2) If so, what has been the level of expenditure on these programs in (a) 1996-97, (b) 1997-98, (c) 1998-99, (d) 1999-2000, (e) 2000-2001 and (f) 2001-2002. (3) In relation to programs which have allowed organisations to apply for funding for the delivery of services or programs, (a) what is the name of each program and (b) what was the level of expenditure in each State in (a) 1996-97, (b) 1997-98, (c) 1998-99, (d) 1999-2000, (e) 2000-2001 and (f) 2001-2002 on each program. (4) In relation to funding under these programs, (a) how many applications were received from within the electoral divisions of (i) Chisholm, (ii) Aston, (iii) Deakin, (iv) Latrobe and (v) Casey, (b) what is the name of each organisation that submitted an application, (c) what was the purpose of the funding being sought in each case, (d) what was the value of funding sought in each case and (e) if the application was successful, (i) what level of funding was granted and (ii) in which federal electoral division is the organisation located. (5) In relation to programs that do not provide for organisations to apply for funding, what was the level of expenditure for each program in the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Aston, (c) Deakin, (d) Latrobe and (e) Casey in (i) 1996-97, (ii) 1997-98, (iii) 1998-99, (iv) 1999-2000, (v) 2000-2001 and (vi) 2001-2002. I am advised by my department as follows: (1) No (2) to (5) N/A Defence: Reserve Units (Question No. 767) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Which Reserve units, companies, battalions or brigades have been designated High Readiness. (2) How many Reservists have been designated High Readiness Reserve and Active Reserve. (3) How many Reservists have been designated High Readiness Reserve without being in a High Readiness Unit. (4) Will such High Readiness Reserves be utilised as slots in Regular Army or in formed Reserve units; if so, what are the criteria for their utilisation. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) None. The authority for Service Chiefs to raise new Reserve categories of service such as High Readiness will not come into effect until new Defence (Personnel) Regulations are passed into law. This process is not likely to occur until 1 December 2002. The size and structure of such a category would be based upon the Army’s preparedness requirements as determined through regular reviews and higher direction. Options are being examined as part of the Army’s development of models for the sustainment of combat forces under guidance provided in the Defence 2000 White Paper. (2) None, at this stage. When the new Defence (Personnel) Regulations come into effect it is planned that members currently serving in the General Reserve will be re-categorised as Active Reservists. (3) None. (4) If a High Readiness category is to be raised it is unlikely that whole units would be designated as High Readiness as the nature of Reserve service would not enable all members to be available at short notice. It is envisaged that should a High Readiness component be established it would be utilised to support Army’s short notice contingencies.
title: Representatives Main Committee Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Howard
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Defence: High Readiness Reserve (Question No. 768) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: What is the period of the notice to move for a High Readiness Reserve and how is that different for a similar Active Reserve (a) individual, (b) unit, (c) company, (d) battalion or (e) brigade. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: No period of notice to move has been specified. Should a High Readiness category be established the period of notice will be based upon the Army’s preparedness requirements. Defence: High Readiness Reserve (Question No. 769) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) What is the training requirement for a High Readiness Reserve and how is that different for a similar Active Reserve (a) individual, (b) unit, (c) company, (d) battalion or (e) brigade. (2) What is the extra dollar investment in training for a High Readiness Reserve (a) individual, (b) unit, (c) company, (d) battalion or (e) brigade. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) As a High Readiness category is yet to be established the specific training requirements and obligations have not been determined. It is envisaged that the fundamental difference between a High Readiness Reservist and an Active Reservist would be the periods of notice in which individuals would be expected to report for full-time service. High Readiness Reservists would be expected to be at a standard that allowed them to deploy at periods of notice similar to many of their Regular Army counterparts. (2) No additional investment has been determined. Defence: High Readiness Reserve (Question No. 770) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Has it been estimated that it costs $4.2 billion to fully equip the Army. (2) What is the estimated cost to fully equip the (a) High Readiness Reserve (i) individual, (ii) unit, (ii) company, (iv) battalion or (v) brigade and the (b) Active Reserve (i) individual, (ii) unit, (iii) company, (iv) battalion or (v) brigade. (3) What additional equipment is being provided for High Readiness Reserve and (a) what is its cost and (b) which units will get what equipment and at what cost. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) No. The Portfolio Budget Statement indicates that the cost of the Army’s total output for 2002/2003 will be $5.192 billion. (2) Cost estimates are yet to be completed. (3) Equipment requirements are yet to be determined. Defence: High Readiness Reserve (Question No. 771) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) How many potential High Readiness and Active Reservists are expected to be recruited in (a) 2002 and (b) 2003. (2) What is the estimated cost per reserve recruit in (a) 2002 and (b) 2003 for (i) advertising and (ii) training. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Army would not expect to recruit directly to the High Readiness Reserve. If such a category is established it is envisaged that members of the High Readiness Reserve would be required to satisfy a selection criteria and would elect to be transferred from other parts of the Army. The number of recruits that may be required to feed new categories is being examined. The Army recruited 2,712 Reserve recruits in financial year 2001/02 and has a recruitment target of 3,098 for financial year 2002/03. (2) (a) 2001/2002 was: (i) $996.00 (ii) $23,594.00 (b) 2002/2003 is estimated at: (i) $839.00 (ii) $25,953.00 Defence: High Readiness Reserves (Question No. 772) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Is there a mechanism for designating High Readiness Reserves or is it done voluntarily; if so, what are the details. (2) What was the mechanism and or criteria for determining which units would be High Readiness Reserve and Active Reserve. Mrs Vale-The minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s questions: (1) If a High Readiness category is raised it would be filled on a voluntary basis. It is envisaged that individuals would be required to satisfy particular proficiency and availability criteria but would be administered within their current Reserve unit. (2) If a High Readiness category is raised it is highly unlikely that whole units or larger formations would be designated High Readiness as the nature of Reserve Service would not enable all members to be available at short notice. The current thinking is that individuals and groups within standing Reserve units and formations may become High Readiness Reserves after satisfying particular criteria. The numbers that might be required are under examination as part of a wider capability development project to meet the Army’s Defence 2000 White Paper requirements. Defence: High Readiness Reserve (Question No. 773) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) What is the proportion of regular army personnel for High Readiness Reserve and Active Reserve (a) units, (b) companies, (c) battalions or (d) brigades. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: There is no plan to change the current allocation of Regular members regardless of any future initiatives to establish new Reserve categories. Defence: Army Reserves (Question No. 774) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Does Army have a plan to close Reserve depots; if so, (a) what is it called and (b) is it publicly available. (2) For each calendar year from 1996 to date, (a) which Reserve depots have closed, (b) where were they located, (c) when did they close and (d) were any sold; if so, for what sum. (3) Are further Reserve depots closures expected; if so, (a) which Reserve depots, (b) what are their locations and (c) when are they expected to close. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Army does not possess a plan that formally depicts which Reserve depots will close. (a) The Army does possess the Army Facilities Plan 2001 which provides guidance for the acquisition, development and environmental management of facilities and training areas appropriate to Army capability outputs. It also contains an annex that outlines Army occupied properties identified for possible disposal. (b) No. (2) (a), (b) and (c) The database information recorded does not specifically identify facilities occupied by Reserve Units as Reserve Depots. Attached is a list of training depots and drill halls that may have accommodated Reserve Units, and which have been sold during the period Financial Year 1995-96 to date. (d) Due to confidentiality limitations, it is inappropriate for Defence to disclose the sale price of the individual properties. (3) Further Reserve depot closures are possible as Defence rationalises its estate. (a), (b) and (c) This information has not been determined. This is dependant on the strategic outlook and capability outputs required by the Army and Defence. Annerley QLD Training Depot Australian Defence Force: Uniforms and Equipment (Question No. 778) Ms George asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Are Australian Defence Force personnel issued with all uniforms and equipment free of charge when beginning their training. (2) If so, can personnel swap worn out, lost or damaged uniforms and equipment on a one for one basis or are they required to pay for all new uniforms and equipment after their initial issue. (3) If personnel are forced to pay for their own replacement uniforms and equipment are they able to claim it back on tax; if not, why not. (4) Is it the case that the families of (a) Navy personnel deployed on operations overseas are able to send mail for no cost up to 3kg, (b) Army personnel deployed on operations overseas are able to send mail for no cost up to 2kg and (c) Air Force personnel deployed on operations overseas are able to send mail for no cost up to 1kg; if so, (d) why are the weights at which families can send mail different for the different services and (e) what action does the Minister intend to take to remedy these discrepancies. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) After the initial free issue, a Uniform Maintenance Allowance is paid to assist members to maintain an approved scale of uniforms in good order and condition. However, provisions exist for field uniforms and equipment that are worn out or damaged due to everyday wear and tear to be exchanged on a one for one basis unless they are lost or damaged through the members’ negligence. In that case replacement of the items must be paid for by the member. Reserve Australian Defence Force members, not on continuous full-time duty, are issued replacement clothing and equipment on a one for one basis. Again, loss or damage of uniforms due to the members negligence requires replacement costs to be met by the member. (3) Uniform Maintenance Allowance is paid to eligible Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel fortnightly as a non-taxed allowance. Personnel are required to justify expenditure on uniform and uniform-related items in their taxation returns at the end of each financial year as per normal workrelated clothing deduction arrangements. ADF personnel in receipt of the Uniform Maintenance Allowance are required to pay tax on any amount of the allowance that cannot be substantiated as expended on the maintenance of their uniforms. (4) ‘Free’ mail limits for ADF personnel deployed overseas do not differ between the three Services. These limits are set by Commander Australian Theatre, in consultation with others, including Australia Post. These limits are based on the nature and location of the operation, as well as logistic support considerations. The cost of sending mail to ADF personnel deployed on operations is subsidised by Defence. The rate of subsidy is determined as a component of the conditions of service for each operation, and thus varies between operations. Currently, operations in East Timor and the Australian contribution to the war on terrorism attract the highest subsidies. For example, a package of up to 20kgs can be sent free of charge to East Timor, where the same package to a member serving in Israel would be charged at the Australian domestic rate applicable from the point of lodgement in Sydney. Mail or packages for personnel deployed as part of the Australian contribution to the war on terrorism are only free up to a limit of 1kg. Anything over 1kg is charged at the Australian domestic rate applicable from the point of lodgement to Sydney. Throsby Electorate: Residential Detoxification Beds (Question No. 779) Ms George asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) How many residential detoxification beds are available in the electoral division of Throsby and where are they located. (2) How many residential detoxification beds are available in the Illawarra area, which hospitals, or non-government organisations provide them and where are they located. (3) How many residential rehabilitation beds are available in the electoral division of Throsby. (4) How many residential rehabilitation beds are available in the Illawarra area, which hospitals, or non-government organisations provide them and where are they located. (5) What facilities exist in the electoral division of Throsby and the wider Illawarra area for the treatment of people suffering from a combined mental illness and drug dependency. (6) Which service providers in the electoral division of Throsby and the wider Illawarra area are offering treatment for people with a drug dependency and what is the nature of their treatment and services. (7) What is the nature of the Commonwealth assistance provided in the electoral division of Throsby and in the wider Illawarra area to assist in the area of prevention and treatment of illicit drug abuse. the honourable member’s question: (1) to (6)The NSW State Government is primarily responsible for the delivery of drug and alcohol services in NSW. Information about services available in the areas specified will need to be provided by the NSW State Government. (7) Under the National Illicit Drugs Strategy the Commonwealth Government provides funding for prevention and treatment of illicit drug use through the Non-Government Organisation (NGO) Treatment Grants Program, the Community Partnerships Initiative and the Council of Australian Government’s (COAG) Drug Diversion Initiative. Details of the funding provided under these programs in the wider Illawarra area is at Attachment A. Particular focus on those with a dual diagnosis. Mission AusIllawarra & Marginalised Extension of drug intervention and treatment $129,000 tralia Ltd. title: Representatives Main Committee Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer toCommunity Partnerships Initiative: Organisation Location Target Group Description of Project Funding Name Over2 years Bellambi Bellambi Women The “Youth Drug Education and Programs $67,000 Neighbour-hood (15-24 years) Team” project aims to invite young women Centre (15-24 years) to participate in a prevention education training program. Ongoing workshops will equip them with skills and knowledge in team work skills, program planning etc. The participants will then form the “Youth Drugs Prevention Advisory Team” that will aim to develop strategies and programs to assess needs; disseminate information about the Team and the aims of the project. Kedesh RehaBerkeley Parents This project aims to further develop and $79,000 bilitation Servevaluate the TANDEM Training Program for ices parents in outer-metropolitan, rural and remote communities. The program is based on the premise that prevention and early intervention must increase young people’s personal and environmental resilience for protection against risk of drug and alcohol misuse. Illawarra Area Health Service. Wollongong Wollongong as above Detoxification and residential rehabili$30,000 Crisis Centre tation Kedesh House Berleley as above Residential rehabilitation $30,000 There are a number of other Statewide programs funded under the Diversion Initiative that provide funding for police cautioning and treatment to divert offenders from the criminal justice system and give an opportunity for drug users to access education and/or treatment. These programs include the: Young Offenders’ Act This Scheme applies to children apprehended by police for a wholly summary drug offence involving not more than the statutory small quantity of the drug, or for an offence that is drug-related. This means police, in appropriate circumstances, can issue a caution or warning, or organise a youth justice conference in lieu of commencing court proceedings and Cannabis Cautioning Scheme The Scheme provides police officers with the discretion to caution adult offenders in relation to the use and possession of dried cannabis and the possession of equipment for the administration of cannabis. A person can only be cautioned if they have no prior convictions for drug offences or offences of violence or sexual assault. Offenders are given written legal and health information on the use of cannabis. The caution also lists the dedicated cannabis phone line for the Alcohol and Drug Information Service (ADIS). From1 September 2001, NSW Police commenced the issue of Second Caution Notices where offenders are required to contact ADIS to undertake a mandatory health education session on the use of cannabis. Defence: Chicquita Park (Question No. 781) Ms Corcoran asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) What was the sale price of the Defence property known as Chicquita Park, located at Levanto Street, Mentone, Vic., sold in December 2001. (2) On what date was (a) the property sold and (b) the sale price agreed upon by the Minister’s Department and the purchaser. (3) What conditions, if any, applied to the sale. (4) How many tenderers submitted a bid. (5) Was the price in the tender of the eventual purchaser the highest price of all tenders. (6) By what process did the Minister’s Department satisfy itself that the final price agreed with the purchaser was a reasonable price for the property. (7) During negotiations with Kingston Council prior to the sale of Chicquita Park, what estimated value did the Minister’s Department place on the property. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Due to confidentiality limitations, it is inappropriate for Defence to disclose the sale price of individual properties. (2) (a) Contracts were exchanged on 20 December 2001 and settlement occurred on 20 March 2002. (b) The price was agreed on 20 December 2001 when a deposit was accepted on the exchange of contracts. (3) The only condition of sale was that the purchaser offered a lease of up to three years to the Mentone Scout Group. (4) Five conforming tenders and four non-conforming tenders were received. (5) No. (6) The department obtained a valuation from a certified valuer in June 2001 indicating a market value for the site of between $2,000,000 and $2,500,000. (7) A valuation based on a residential zoning was obtained in 1999 and the market value of the property at that time was estimated at $2,900,000. Defence: Staffing (Question No. 800) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 August 2002: (1) How many (a) full time permanent staff, (b) part time permanent staff, (c) full time contract staff and (d) part time contract staff were employed by (i) the Minister’s Department and (ii) agencies within the Minister’s portfolio as at (A) 30 March 1996 and (B) 30 June 2002. (2) For each category of engagement referred to in part (1) and employed by (a) the Minister’s Department and (b) agencies within the Minister’s portfolio, where were such persons located in (i) 30 March 1996 and (ii) 30 June 2002. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (A) The information sought by the honourable member in relation to part (1)(A) and part (2)(i) of his question is not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the use of the resources that would be required to provide that information. I am able to inform the honourable member, however, that data on APS staffing as at 30 June 1996 is contained in the Australian Public Service Statistical Bulletin 1995-1996 which is publicly available. The honourable member should be aware, however, that changes in APS functions and administrative arrangements between 1996 and 2002 may render direct comparisons between the data for those years invalid. (B) See attached table – Number of personnel in the Australian Defence Organisation as at June 2002. (2) (i) See (1) (A) above. (ii) See attached table – Employee numbers by State in the Australian Defence Organisation as at June 2002. (2) What were the countries of origin of these visa holders. (3) Of those issued a secondary movement relocation visa, how many were (a) partners and (b) children of temporary protection visa holders who are already in Australia. (4) Are temporary protection visas for 3 years duration and Secondary Movement Relocation visas for 5 years; if so, does this mean that the Government proposes to review separately, and at different times, the continuing need for protection of individual family members. (1) As at 6 September 2002, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) had issued 119 Secondary Movement Relocation (subclass 451) (SMR) visas: 34 SMR visas were issued to persons residing in Indonesia; and 85 SMR visas were issued to persons residing in Nauru. (2) As at 6 September 2002, DIMIA had issued SMR visas to: 107 Iraqi nationals; 1 Iranian national; 3 Afghani nationals; 4 Palestinian nationals; and 4 stateless persons. (3) As at 6 September 2002 of the 119 persons issued with SMR visas: (a) 31 were partners of Temporary Protection Visa (TPV) holders already in Australia; and (b) 66 were minors with a parent TPV holder already in Australia. (4) TPVs are issued for a period of 3 years and SMR visas are issued for a period of 5 years. It is possible that members of a single family unit who have arrived in Australia under different circumstances or at different times have been issued with different temporary humanitarian visa types with different expiry dates. It is therefore possible that they may have any subsequent claims for
title: Attachment A

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:ongoing protection considered at different times. However, holders of these visas in Australia are able to lodge further applications for protection at any time and the Minister is able to decide such applications at any time. Opportunities thus exist for the Minister to align the terms of visas subsequently granted to family groups, if appropriate, should they apply together. Defence: Director of Military Prosecutions (Question No. 834) Mr Price asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 August 2002: (1) What is the full year budget cost of the office of the Inspector-General of the Australian Defence Force following the appointment of the Acting Justice of the Supreme Court, Justice Peter Newsman, to the position. (2) When will the Director of Military Prosecutions be appointed. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) $1,018,700.00. (2) The creation of a Director of Military Prosecutions will require legislative change to the Defence Force Discipline Act. Pending legislative change an interim Director of Military Prosecutions model will be put in place. The Chiefs of Service Committee will consider the final interim model in October 2002, with the interim Director of Military Prosecutions commencing operations in 2003. Foreign Affairs: Iraq (Question No. 841) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 August 2002: (1) Is he aware of Channel Nines Sunday programs claim that 13% of oil for food revenue is to be distributed to the Kurdish population in Northern Iraq. (2) Is he able to say why the World Health Organisation (WHO) allows Baghdad to distribute or not distribute medicines brought under the oil for food program to the Kurdish region. (3) Is he able to say whether US$250 million is being earmarked for Kurdistan per annum, and about $200 million per annum remains in accounts controlled by the regime in Iraq. (4) Is he also able to say whether there are widespread shortages of key medicines in Kurdistan and Northern Iraq. (5) Has the Australian Government had representatives visit Kurdistan since the establishment of the northern no fly zone. (6) Has the Australian Government made representations to the WHO about the more equitable distribution of the oil for food plan; if not, why not. (1) Yes. United Nations’ resolutions stipulate that 13 per cent of total revenue from the Oil-for-Food Programme will fund the humanitarian programme in the three northern governorates of Iraq. (2) The United Nations Inter-Agency Humanitarian Programme is responsible for the storage, handling, internal transportation, distribution and confirmation of equitable distribution of humanitarian supplies in the three northern governorates. Distribution is not undertaken in these three northern governorates by the Iraqi Regime. (3) Money raised from the Oil-for-Food Programme is placed into UN escrow accounts and is not controlled by the Iraqi Regime. The total annual revenue collected by the Oil-for-Food Programme, 13 per cent of which funds the humanitarian programme for the three northern governorates, fluctuates depending on oil sales made by Iraq and changes in oil price. (4) Yes. A UN Secretary-General report released in November 2001 pursuant to UNSCR 1360 indicates significant shortages of domestically produced medicines and medical supplies, and periodic shortages of imported medicines and medical supplies in the three northern governorates. (5) Yes.
title: Total Nsw Vic Qld Sa Wa Tas Nt Act O S Total Personnel

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(6) No. According to a technical report prepared by the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the UN in 2000, improvements in the nutritional situation in the north started in 1994, prior to UNSCR 986 (1995). This is due to greater resources in the north – the north has 9 per cent of the land area of Iraq but nearly 50 per cent of the productive arable land – and receives higher levels of assistance per person. The north also benefits from the greater flexibility the use of cash gives agencies for the more effective operation and management of programmes. Foreign Affairs: Iran (Question No. 857) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 2002: (1) Is he able to say whether in July 2002 there were mass demonstrations in Tehran calling for the end of the Islamic Republic. (2) Is he able to say whether six leading members of Irans notorious Revolutionary Guard issued a communiqué in support of the people of Iran. (3) Is he able to say whether the Grand Ayatollah Taheri of Esfehan openly sided with student demonstrators, calling on the ruling theocracy to give up power. (4) Is he able to say whether Ayatollah Taheris announcement against the tyranny of the current Iranian regime also included a defence of Ayatollah Montazeri, one of the most outspoken domestic critics of Iran who has been under house arrest for years. (5) Is he able to say whether Ayatollah Taheris announcement applauded Montazeris fatwah or ruling against the practice of suicide bombing. (6) Is he able to say whether ayatollahs from Qom have been in clandestine contact with the son of the late Shah of Iran asking him to send cassettes verbalizing a message of non-violent civil disobedience against the regime. (7) Is he able to say whether during the demonstrations, the Iranian police force was confined to barracks and foreigners with paramilitary training, chiefly Palestinian and Iraqi Arabs, and Uzbeks and Tadzhiks from Afghanistan, were sent to beat the demonstrators down. (8) Is he also able to say whether during these demonstrations the protestors also denounced President Mohammad Khatami. (1) On9 July 2002 there were demonstrations in Tehran of an estimated 4,000 people protesting ongoing imprisonment of student leaders arrested three years previously and calling for increased freedom and greater regard for human rights. (2) I am unaware of any such communiqué. (3) No. (4) Yes. (5) No. (6) I have no evidence to substantiate or discount such a claim. (7) No. (8) Yes. Immigration: Managed Migration-Who Does the Managing (Question No. 900) Ms Gillard asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 16 September 2002: Did he recently circulate a colour brochure on his presentation entitled, “Managed Migration – Who does the Managing?”; if so, (a) what sum did the brochure cost to produce, (b) what was its print run and (c) to whom was it circulated. Yes, a colour booklet was produced by my Department containing an edited version of a presentation I made to senior government officials and academics in the United Kingdom on 16 August 2002.
title: Total Nsw Vic Qld Sa Wa Tas Nt Act O S Total Personnel

speaker: Mr Downer
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Total Nsw Vic Qld Sa Wa Tas Nt Act O S Total Personnel

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(a) The booklet cost $2,025.68 to produce. (b) To date 453 copies of the booklet have been printed. (c) The booklet was distributed to media at a press conference I held on Thursday 22 August 2002. It was subsequently circulated to all Members and Senators and is available to the public on my website <www.minister.immi.gov.au>. In addition, approximately 50 copies of the booklet were used for internal purposes.
title: Total Nsw Vic Qld Sa Wa Tas Nt Act O S Total Personnel
